definitions.definition: to say or write something in the form of a question, in order to get information
definitions.sensetop: ask about somebody/somethingask something+ speechask somebody + speechask somebody somethingask somebody about somethingask where, what, etc…ask somebody where, what, etc…

examples.text: How old are you—if you don’t **mind me/my asking**?
He asked about her family.
Can I **ask a question**?
Did you ask the price?
You do what I tell you to, **no questions asked**.
There are three important questions to ask.
frequently asked questions
‘Where are you going?’ she asked.
‘Are you sure?’ he asked her.
She asked the students their names.
I often **get asked** that!
I had to ask myself some very difficult questions.
I'd like to ask you a few questions.
Why does everyone keep asking me that?
The interviewer asked me about my future plans.
When specifically **asked about the report**, she indicated she had not read it.
He asked where I lived.
I had to ask the teacher what to do next.
I was asked if/whether I could drive.
I wondered how old she was but I didn't dare ask.
‘Do you still want to go out tonight?’ she asked hopefully.
‘How do you feel?’ she asked softly.
‘Oh, Sue went too, did she?’ I asked innocently.
‘Will he be all right?’ Sabrina asked anxiously.
I wanted to ask him a question.
May I ask what you mean by that?
Voters can legitimately ask whose interests are being served by the new legislation.
She longed to ask Mary if she knew what was wrong.

phrases: if you don’t mind me asking
if you don’t mind my asking

definitions.definition: to tell somebody that you would like them to do something or that you would like something to happen
definitions.sensetop: ask somebody to do somethingask whether, what, etc…ask somebody whether, what, etc…ask that…
definitions.labels: (formal)(British English also)(informal or North American English)

examples.text: Anyone with information is **asked to contact** the police.
Parents with young children are asked to attend this meeting.
They were politely asked to leave the shop.
Eric asked me to marry him.
All the students were asked to complete a questionnaire.
I asked whether they could change my ticket.
She asked me if I would give her English lessons.
She asked that she be kept informed of developments.
She asked that she should be kept informed.
If you ask her nicely, she'll give you a hand.

definitions.definition: to say that you would like somebody to give you something
definitions.sensetop: ask for somethingask somethingask somebody for somethingask something of somebodyask somebody something

examples.text: Don't be afraid to **ask for help**.
I am writing to ask for some information about courses.
to ask for a job/a drink/an explanation
Did your friend ask for permission to use the image?
Why don't you ask his advice?
Why don't you ask him for his advice?
Can I ask a favour of you?
Can I ask you a favour?
I'm not asking for money.
I went up to the counter and asked for a lemonade.
If you want anything, just ask.
Why don't you ask your teacher for some of her thoughts on the matter?

definitions.definition: to request permission to do something
definitions.sensetop: ask to do somethingask if, whether, etc…ask somebody if, whether, etc…

examples.text: I immediately asked to speak to a supervisor.
I asked to see the manager.
Did you ask to use the car?
I'll ask if it's all right to park here.
She asked her boss whether she could have the day off.

definitions.sensetop: ask somebody + adv./prep.ask somebodyask somebody to do something
definitions.labels: (informal or North American English)(British English)(North American English)

examples.text: They've asked me to dinner.
Thank you so much for asking me.
I didn't ask them in *(= to come into the house)*.
We must ask the neighbours round *(= to our house)*.
She's asked him to come to the party.

definitions.definition: to request a particular amount of money for something that you are selling

examples.text: **He's asking** £2 000 for the car.
How much **were they asking** for their house?

definitions.sensetop: ask somethingask something of somebodyask something to do something

examples.text: I know I'm asking a great deal.
You're asking too much of him.
I know it's asking a lot to expect them to win again.

definitions.definition: to deserve something bad that happens to you or that somebody does to you

examples.text: ‘You shouldn’t have said that to her.’ ‘Well, she asked for it!’

definitions.definition: to behave in a way that is very likely to result in trouble

examples.text: He was asking for trouble when he insulted their country.

definitions.definition: if you say don’t ask to somebody, you mean that you do not want to reply to their question, because it would be difficult to explain, embarrassing, etc.

examples.text: ‘And what did he do then?’ ‘Don’t ask!’

definitions.definition: if you say don’t ask me, you mean that you do not know the answer to a question and are annoyed you have been asked

examples.text: ‘What will the meeting be about?’ ‘Don’t ask me.’

definitions.definition: if you can have something for the asking, it is very easy for you to get it if you ask for it

examples.text: The job is yours for the asking.

definitions.definition: if you say I ask you, you are expressing shock, anger or a strong feeling of dislike about something/somebody

examples.text: He told me I had to work late on Friday night. I ask you!
Their marriage was a mistake, if you ask me.

wordOrigin: Old English āscian, āhsian, āxian, of West Germanic origin.
